content: Very good puzzle. You could have enhanced it a bit more by varying the number of tiles in x and y directions

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Beautiful puzzle. If the code works up to test 4, all the other tests will be ok as well (I think), so it is fair that it is classified as easy, and then it is a beautiful surprise to see all those tile patterns flashing by in the output.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think that for an easy puzzle it's ok.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Do you know Python Lisa-Has-Ideas? This puzzle, just like several of your other puzzles, is an absolute dream for somebody practicing the basics of Numpy Arrays in Python. For anybody doing Python, I think you are missing out on a tremendous opportunity if you aren't playing around with Numpy on this puzzle. It was super fun to watch 50 test cases / validators get cranked out. I know this is just part of who you are, but we always appreciate your detailed and comprehensive approach to test cases. The write-up is well done and easy to follow. Great job!

Goal section
* Suggest to change "contents" to "pattern".

* Details point 3: Suggest to mention "(excluding the borders)".

* Details point 4: {{-}} are also for the bottom borders, and also ALL borders are sides. So I would suggest to rewrite point 4 to something like:
Each Tile is defined by horizontal borders {{-}}, vertical borders {{|}} and corners {{+}}, and those characters are shared between common borders of two adjacent Tiles.

* Suggest to mention that the borders/corners have to be included in the output, even though they are not given in the input.

* Flip/Mirror patterns: Suggest to delete "sometimes" (isn't it always? unless you're thinking of the same thing that I'll mention in my next comment...).

Constraints section
* Is it correct to state that in the input:
   ‚Ä¢ () {} [] <> /\ never appear as the last character in each line, and
   ‚Ä¢ ^v AV wm WM un /\ never appear in the last line?

(I'm thinking that if I'm given an input of, e.g.
^[{
v]/
vu\
I need to check whether the first two characters in Line 1 and Line 2 need to be flipped/mirrored, right? But the rest of the characters will definitely break symmetry.)

Input section
* Please change n to N for consistency.

* Would like to see more precise description than "row(s) of input" e.g. "row(s) of Tile pattern in the top left quadrant".

Cases
* Test case 1: There is an extra space in the last line of input. (I have not checked the other cases.)

* Interestingly ^ is not found in any of the input :)

Thanks.

Thank you so much for your eagle-eye and insightful comments, as always.

I'm not thinking of the border as part of the tile.  I'm thinking of it as the "grout" around the tiles, so I re-worded it as that.

I don't want to use the term "quadrant" in the input, because the input is slightly more than exactly 1/4.

I added a test case of ^v (I accidentally left those out of my program that I used to create all the test cases.... amazing that you caught that !!!)

"Sometimes" is correct.  For example, you don't always flip a "M" to an "W" -- you only flip those when flipping down, not when flipping sideways.  So that is why I'm saying sometimes.

You said:
* Is it correct to state that in the input:
   ‚Ä¢ () {} [] <> /\ never appear as the last character in each line, and
   ‚Ä¢ ^v AV wm WM un /\ never appear in the last line?
...Yes, that is correct

(I will check all the input for extra spaces)

If you don't mind, please review again and let me know.

Thanks, I appreciate the approval and kind words.

I've watched Python videos :) but am still a novice in that, so I will have to add "Numpy Arrays" to my "Stuff to learn" list :)

Making 50 cases is very soothing to me; I'm glad you enjoy :)

If you liked this puzzle, please consider upvoting my latest one (which is similar but different) at:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5195754d8ced8c1119d5a67c4693952b3e8fd
Thank ya !
Thanks !!!

Thank you.  And that's a good point.  I just always think of a tile as "square".

Hey, if you liked this puzzle, please consider upvoting my other pending-similar one, at https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5195754d8ced8c1119d5a67c4693952b3e8fd

Actually I am curious about the numpy part. I usually prefer to use numpy arrays whenever I get the chance (very easy working with xD arrays, its different axes, and boolean slicing), but for solving this one I found it easier to simply use the string.replace() method. Are you using numpy for selecting cells with a certain character and replacing them, or is there another perfect use for numpy in this puzzle that I did not see?

Thank you for your praise and explanation! :D

I'm more than happy to review it again :wink:

I now understand and agree with you on the points on border/grout and quadrant. Grout is a nice change in the explanation, more easily visualised than the slightly more abstract concept of border!

Comments based on the revised version:

Goal section
* Details point 2: Suggest not to format "full" in bold. Suggest to format instead "top left" and "middle" in bold.

* Details point 4: Suggest to change "sides" to "left/right".

Input section
* Line 1: Suggest to change "input" to "partial Tile pattern".

Cases
* As a more thorough check, this time I ran through all the inputs by writing a program instead of with my eyes. The tests cover all the special characters, but the validators do not cover these yet: ( M W ^ u v. Please adjust the validators.

Thanks again :)

Thanks again !
I made those changes and changed Validator 25.

Interesting note: 25 is the limit for how many test/validators are allowed :)

lol, I didn't know that limit, interesting to know :)

Now 2 characters have not been covered in the validators: ( and M. Maybe slight adjustments to Validators 7 and 10 would fix that?

Thanks again.

Thanks, again! Done.  :)
I did as you suggested: Validator 7 and Validator 10.
(I also slightly changed Test 10.)

Please let me know if you see anything else.

I'm thinking of putting this as "Ready" in a few days.
The revised version looks ok! üëç
I see that you use "quarterSize" as the variable name in the other floor tile puzzle. Would you consider using the same name here?

Thanks for the feedback on my other "Tile a Floor" puzzle (now called "Tile a Floor Differently").

I don't want to call the variable in THIS puzzle "quarterSize" because that is not precisely accurate.  (It's a little bit more, since all the full Tiles in this puzzle are odd numbers)
Oh, sorry, I wasn't aware of that difference, my bad.
I've added the word "Next" in Input section just now.
